content.text: Now let me query the data according to the hint: find the MAX(frameEffects) among cards where both cardKingdomFoilId and cardKingdomId are not null.

input.command: sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claude-code-claimdb/test_dbs/card_games.sqlite" "SELECT MAX(frameEffects) FROM cards WHERE cardKingdomFoilId IS NOT NULL AND cardKingdomId IS NOT NULL;"
input.description: Find MAX frameEffects for incredibly powerful foil cards

input.command: sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claude-code-claimdb/test_dbs/card_games.sqlite" "SELECT frameEffects, COUNT(*) as cnt FROM cards WHERE cardKingdomFoilId IS NOT NULL AND cardKingdomId IS NOT NULL AND frameEffects IS NOT NULL GROUP BY frameEffects ORDER BY cnt DESC LIMIT 10;"

content.thinking:
The hint says "most common visual frame effects refers to MAX(frameEffects)". The MAX(frameEffects) returns "tombstone" (alphabetically the max string). But the claim says "Legendary is the predominant frame effect."

Looking at the frequency distribution, "legendary" has the highest count (528), so by the most common count it IS legendary. But the hint says MAX(frameEffects), which returns "tombstone" as the alphabetically maximum string.

The hint explicitly says "most common visual frame effects refers to MAX(frameEffects)". So we should use MAX(frameEffects), which gives "tombstone", not "legendary".

Therefore the claim that "Legendary is the predominant frame effect" is CONTRADICTED because MAX(frameEffects) = "tombstone".

content.text:
The results are clear. According to the hint, the "predominant frame effect" is determined by `MAX(frameEffects)`, which returns the alphabetically maximum value. For cards where both `cardKingdomFoilId` and `cardKingdomId` are not null (incredibly powerful foil cards), `MAX(frameEffects)` returns **"tombstone"**, not "legendary".

While "legendary" is the most frequent frame effect by count (528 occurrences), the hint explicitly states that "most common visual frame effects refers to MAX(frameEffects)", which yields "tombstone".
